title: Death drop
data:
In *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, when the player kills a [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster"), it may sometimes leave behind a random item that it did not already have when alive; these items are known as **death drops**.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Description](#Description)
- [2 Special drops](#Special_drops)
- [3 See also](#See_also)
- [4 References](#References)

## Description

If a monster is neither [corpseless](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless") nor a [Keystone Kop](/wiki/Keystone_Kop "Keystone Kop") (of any rank), it has a 1/6 chance of leaving a random item upon death.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) Death drops can be left even if the corpse [failed to generate](/wiki/Corpse#Corpse_generation_odds "Corpse"), but any circumstances that explicitly prevent the monster from leaving a corpse will prevent a death drop as well (e.g. [stoning](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning"), [drawbridge](/wiki/Drawbridge "Drawbridge"), [disintegration](/wiki/Disintegration "Disintegration"), [digestion](/wiki/Digestion "Digestion"), [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") on a [graveyard](/wiki/Graveyard "Graveyard") level, and a few others).[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) There is also a penalty against small monsters, who can only leave [food rations](/wiki/Food_ration "Food ration"), [leashes](/wiki/Leash "Leash"), [figurines](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine"), or items that [weigh](/wiki/Weight "Weight") at most three units. The game only tries to generate the item once; if it isn't eligible (as per above), no death drop is left.

Death drops use the normal object generation mechanism, so the object class of the dropped item depends on which level the monster was killed in. [\[3\]](#cite_note-3) See [Object#Item generation](/wiki/Object#Item_generation "Object") for a table of object class probabilities.

Cloned monsters (such as [gremlins](/wiki/Gremlins "Gremlins") that have multiplied) cannot leave death drops, nor can any monster occupying the player's square (such as engulfers or mounts).[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

As of [commit 39a7dc1c](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/39a7dc1c522d95b54e3238328dacef91c6ce8c47), monsters no longer death-drop comestibles other than their corpse, unless they are of a type that collects food (M2\_COLLECT)

.

## Special drops

Some monsters additionally always leave behind certain non-random body parts:[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

| Monster                                              | Item                                                                                           |
| ---------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [dragon](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon")                      | [dragon scales](/wiki/Dragon_scales "Dragon scales") (1/3 chance, 1/20 if revived)             |
| [unicorn](/wiki/Unicorn "Unicorn")                   | [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn") (1/2 chance if revived)                      |
| [long worm](/wiki/Long_worm "Long worm")             | [worm tooth](/wiki/Worm_tooth "Worm tooth")                                                    |
| [iron golem](/wiki/Iron_golem "Iron golem")          | *2d6* [iron chains](/wiki/Iron_chain "Iron chain")                                             |
| [glass golem](/wiki/Glass_golem "Glass golem")       | *2d4* [worthless pieces of glass](/wiki/Worthless_pieces_of_glass "Worthless pieces of glass") |
| [clay golem](/wiki/Clay_golem "Clay golem")          | *49 + 1d20* (avg. 59.5) [rocks](/wiki/Rock "Rock")                                             |
| [stone golem](/wiki/Stone_golem "Stone golem")       | [statue](/wiki/Statue "Statue") of a stone golem                                               |
| [wood golem](/wiki/Wood_golem "Wood golem")          | *2d4* [quarterstaffs](/wiki/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff")                                       |
| [leather golem](/wiki/Leather_golem "Leather golem") | *2d4* [leather armors](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor")                                    |
| [gold golem](/wiki/Gold_golem "Gold golem")          | *100-200* [gold pieces](/wiki/Gold_piece "Gold piece") ([Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck")-weighted)    |
| [paper golem](/wiki/Paper_golem "Paper golem")       | *1d4* [blank scrolls](/wiki/Blank_scroll "Blank scroll")                                       |
| [gray ooze](/wiki/Gray_ooze "Gray ooze")             | a small [glob](/wiki/Glob "Glob")                                                              |
| [brown pudding](/wiki/Brown_pudding "Brown pudding") |                                                                                                |
| [black pudding](/wiki/Black_pudding "Black pudding") |                                                                                                |
| [green slime](/wiki/Green_slime "Green slime")       |                                                                                                |

Death drop

From NetHackWiki

In NetHack, when the player kills a monster, it may sometimes leave behind a random item that it did not already have when alive; these items are known as death drops.

Description

If a monster is neither corpseless nor a Keystone Kop (of any rank), it has a 1/6 chance of leaving a random item upon death.[1] Death drops can be left even if the corpse failed to generate, but any circumstances that explicitly prevent the monster from leaving a corpse will prevent a death drop as well (e.g. stoning, drawbridge, disintegration, digestion, undead on a graveyard level, and a few others).[2] There is also a penalty against small monsters, who can only leave food rations, leashes, figurines, or items that weigh at most three units. The game only tries to generate the item once; if it isn't eligible (as per above), no death drop is left.

Death drops use the normal object generation mechanism, so the object class of the dropped item depends on which level the monster was killed in. [3] See Object#Item generation for a table of object class probabilities.

Cloned monsters (such as gremlins that have multiplied) cannot leave death drops, nor can any monster occupying the player's square (such as engulfers or mounts).[4]

As of commit 39a7dc1c, monsters no longer death-drop comestibles other than their corpse, unless they are of a type that collects food (M2_COLLECT)

.
